mnemonic.text: To remember this kana, find the capital "
" inside of it. This "A" will tell you that this kana is also "a" aka あ. There is another similar kana, お, but that one doesn't have an "A" in it, which is how you can differentiate them.
To remember this kana, just think of a couple of
ls (i) hanging out. They're upright because they're trying to mimic the letter "i" which also stands upright and also happens to be the way you spell out this character in romaji.
To remember this kana, notice the "
" shape right in it! It's sideways but it's there, telling you what this kana is.
To remember this kana, think of it like an
xotic bird. The big feathery thing on its head gives it away that it's exotic and not normal. It also lays exotic
ggs, because it's an exotic bird, after all.
Can you see the letter "

" in here, two times? This one looks similar to あ, except for its one key difference: there are two letter "o" symbols visible in there. Make sure you use this to differentiate this kana (お) and that similar kana (あ). This is one area of hiragana where a lot of people trip up, but by using this mnemonic you will be able to figure them out every time.
To remember this, think of someone who's doing the "
n-
n" (ka) dance. The か kana even looks like someone doing the Can-Can.
To remember this, notice how much it resembles a key (ki).
To remember this, think of this kana being the mouth of a coo-coo/cuckoo (ku) bird popping out saying "ku ku, ku ku!"
You'll have to use your imagination here, but this kana looks a lot like a keg. The three dimensional shape that it makes is somewhat
g-like, right?
Ko is a couple of
-habitation (ko) worms. They're so happy together, co-habitating the same area! Alternatively, you could imagine a couple of short
rds laying on the ground next to each other.
This kana looks like a weird sign (where the "si" of "
gn" is pronounced like "sa") stuck in the ground. Focus on the pronunciation, not the spelling, from this mnemonic.
This kana looks like a giant hook you're dipping into the water. What do you catch? A poor
l (shi).
See the
wing (su) doing a loop-dee-loop throwing that poor kid off of it? Imagine him screaming "I'M GONNA SUE SOMEBODY FOR THIIIIIiiiissss" as he flies off into the distance.
This kana looks like a mouth with a big fang in it. What would someone like this say (se)? How
xy is that tooth, btw?
This kana is just a
ngbird (so), flapping its little wings while singing a little tune! "
This looks just like the romaji that spells it out: "
This is the second "exception" hiragana. Instead of a "ti" sound, it is a "chi" sound. Try not to forget this.
This is another "exception" hiragana. Instead of saying "tu" you say "tsu." Try not to forget this.
This kana looks like the uppercase letter "T" where "T" is for "
n." How many kana can you learn at one time? I bet at least ten of them (let's start with the next set!)
This kana looks just like someone's
(to) with a little nail or splinter in it. Imagine how much this would hurt if it was your toe!
The
ughty (na) nun is praying in front of the cross, asking for forgiveness of her naughty ways.
Do you see the
dle (ni) pulling the thread?
This kana looks like some

dles (nu). There are several other kana that are similar to this one (れ, め, ね, わ) but you know this one is noodles because there are no sharp sides in it. It's 100% smooth and bendable, like noodles! It even has an extra loop at the back, because it is a noodle.
This is

lly the cat. There are other kana very similar to this one (ぬ, れ, め, わ) but you know this is different because it has a loop at the end for the tail and it's not super bendable like ぬ (noodles) is (see those sharp corners on the left?).
See the big pig
se (no) there? You can also think of this as a "No smoking" sign (the ones with the cigarette and the big red circle and slash through it). Pick the one that sticks with you the best.
This kana looks like the uppercase letter "H" plus the lowercase letter "a." What does that spell? "
(hi) has a big nose. See that big nose? Now say it out loud. "He has a big nose."

Usually this kana is pronounced with an "f" (fu) in hiragana, so we're going to go with that. However, this kana does look a lot like a hula dancer too, so keep the "hu" in mind as well. If you want, you can think of this hula dancer as a "
-reaky
la dancer" to remember the fu.
Do you know the famous mountain Mt. Saint
lens? This kana isn't totally flat like Helens is, but it's pretty squat looking. That's why this one is Helens.
The left side line is a chimney. The right side is a mutated Santa Claus. He has four arms, a snake tail, and no head. Out of his neck he's uttering "
ho ho… ho ho ho…"
Removing your head? Doubling your hands and arms? What sort of evil
gic is this? What makes it weirder is that your mama is the one doing this magic. Imagine your
looking like this. Aghh!
Looks like lucky number 21. Who just hit the blackjack?
(mi)! Who just turned 21 as well? Me (mi)!!
" (mu), says the cow. "MOOOOOOO."
Look at that beautiful eye! It's so beautiful because of the
keup (me) on it. Gotta look pretty in those eyes!
You want to catch
re (も) fish so you add more worms to your hook. This is the third "hook" one, so make sure you can differentiate the mnemonics in your head: し, つ, and now も.
Do you see the
k in this kana?
This kana is a very
nique (yu) looking fish! It looks like a big eyeball swimming in the water.
The hitchhiker has his arm and thumb out. He's yelling "
! yo!" at all the cars that go past him. Why won't they pick him up?
The
pper is rapping at the DJ table.
The
ds (ri) are swaying in the wind.
The is like ろ (you'll learn it in a second) except it has a loop at the end. る is a crazier route (ru). There is a loop (ru) at the end. Are there no rules on this road?
This looks like a guy kneeling on the ground,
tching up his dinner.
This is the counterpart to る, except this one doesn't have a loop at the end (there are rules here!). So, this kana is just a plain old road (ro).
This kana looks like a
sp flying straight up.
The "w" is pretty silent, though it's still a tiny bit there. You can pretty much just pronounce it like お.
This kana looks just like the lowercase "
" in English. They happen to be the same sounds, as well. How convenient! nnnんんん.
